summary: This crew conducts comprehensive internet research on a given topic, using specific keywords and considering additional information, to produce a detailed report.
name: Deep Research

researcher.goal: Conduct comprehensive internet research on {research_topic} using {keywords} by performing an exhaustive search that includes academic papers, industry reports, and reputable news sources, focusing on content for a detailed report, and considering {additional_information}
researcher.backstory: Expert academic researcher with a background in scholarly publishing and bibliometrics. Known for discovering hard-to-find information, connecting complex data points, and maintaining impeccable citation records. Specializes in thorough, detailed research with proper attribution and source verification. Has assisted in numerous peer-reviewed publications and understands the importance of academic integrity and proper citation practices. Your specialty is conducting thorough research that leaves no stone unturned, validating facts across multiple reliable sources.

tools.name: SerperDevTool
tools.description: A tool that can be used to search the internet with a search_query.

tools.name: WebsiteSearchTool
tools.description: A tool that can be used to semantic search a query from a specific URL content.

analyst.goal: Analyze, synthesize, and attribute research findings on {research_topic} related to {keywords} with proper citation by conducting a multi-faceted analysis that identifies thematic connections, evaluates source credibility, and synthesizes conflicting viewpoints, while integrating {additional_information}
analyst.backstory: Expert research analyst with a background in academic publication and meta-analysis. Skilled at processing complex information, identifying key patterns and insights, while maintaining rigorous citation standards. Specializes in clear, actionable analysis with meticulous source attribution. Has experience in systematic reviews and maintaining citation integrity throughout the analytical process. Committed to academic rigor and ensuring all insights can be traced back to their original sources. Your analytical mind excels at identifying patterns that others miss, evaluating source credibility, and extracting actionable insights from large volumes of research data.

writer.goal: Create a comprehensive, properly cited, and professionally formatted research report on {research_topic} incorporating {keywords}, based on the comprehensive analysis provided, ensuring a multi-perspective and deeply evidenced narrative, and addressing {additional_information}
writer.backstory: Expert academic writer with extensive experience in scholarly publishing and technical documentation. Specializes in transforming complex analyses into thorough, well-structured documents with proper formatting, comprehensive sections, detailed explanations, and professional presentation. Has published in peer-reviewed journals and understands citation standards across multiple academic styles (APA, MLA, Chicago, etc.). Meticulous about maintaining citation integrity, preventing plagiarism, and ensuring all claims are properly attributed. Known for producing reports that exceed 2000+ words with impeccable citation practices and formatting that would meet academic publication standards.

tasks.description: Research this topic thoroughly: {research_topic} using these keywords: {keywords}, considering {additional_information}.IMPORTANT: Your goal is to gather 25-50 diverse, high-quality sources to ensure comprehensive coverage.Detailed steps:1. Identify primary keywords and concepts related to the topic2. Break down the topic into at least 5-10 subtopics or aspects to explore3. For each subtopic, use the search tool to find 5-10 highly relevant articles, studies, or reputable web pages4. Ensure diversity in your sources, including academic journals, industry reports, news articles, government publications, and reputable websites5. When possible, look for sources with differing perspectives or methodologies to provide a well-rounded view6. For each source, use the website tool to extract key information, data points, evidence, and author/source details7. Use multiple search queries with varied keywords to avoid bias in search results8. Consider using advanced search operators to find specialized information (e.g., site:.edu, site:.gov, filetype:pdf)9. For each source, record complete citation information including: author names, publication date, title, publisher/website name, URL, DOI (if available), and page numbers (if applicable)10. Assign each source a unique identifier [1], [2], etc., for easy reference11. When extracting information, maintain a clear link between each piece of information and its source using the identifier12. Evaluate the credibility and recency of each source using criteria such as author expertise, publication reputation, peer-review status, and currency13. Note the methodology used in research studies to assess the reliability of findings14. Organize findings by theme or subtopic, with each data point explicitly linked to its citation15. For each key finding, identify and document at least 3-5 different perspectives or viewpoints from the sources, noting the nuances of each.16. Focus on content type: detailed report17. Document any conflicting evidence or viewpoints18. Identify any gaps in the research that might require additional investigation19. Aim to gather at least 25-50 high-quality sources to ensure comprehensive coverage of the topic

tasks.name: Comprehensive Research

tasks.description: Perform an in-depth, comprehensive analysis of the research findings on: {research_topic} using keywords: {keywords} and considering {additional_information}.IMPORTANT: Develop a completely original organizational framework based SOLELY on the research material, NOT on any predetermined structure or template.Detailed steps:1. Thoroughly review all research findings and sources provided by the researcher, ensuring you understand the breadth of the 25-50 sources2. IMPORTANT: Develop a completely original organizational framework based SOLELY on the research material, NOT on any predetermined structure or template3. Identify the main thematic areas that emerged from the research (could range from 3 to 15 major themes)4. For each thematic area, create a hierarchy of main topics and subtopics5. Consider whether a chronological, thematic, comparative, problem/solution, or other organizational approach best suits the material6. Determine if certain topics deserve greater emphasis (more sections) based on the amount and quality of research available7. Experiment with different possible structures before settling on the one that best presents the research findings8. Do not feel constrained by traditional report formats - create a structure that best serves this specific topic and research9. For each main theme, identify 3-7 key insights supported by multiple sources and specific evidence10. Conduct a citation analysis to identify which sources are most frequently cited or considered most authoritative11. Identify connections, relationships, and interdependencies between different themes and subtopics12. Compare and contrast different perspectives, methodologies, or conclusions found across the sources13. Always maintain the connection between insights and their original sources14. When presenting data or claims, include the citation information in parentheses (Author, Year) [X], where X is the source's unique identifier15. Keep track of all sources used for each section of your analysis, ensuring comprehensive coverage across the 25-50 sources16. Analyze trends, patterns, and relationships between different aspects of the research topic17. Evaluate the strength and quality of evidence supporting each major claim, noting methodological strengths or limitations18. Identify gaps, contradictions, or areas needing further exploration19. Assess research biases and limitations by evaluating at least 5 factors, such as author affiliation, funding sources, publication bias, selection bias, and methodological limitations.20. Consider how the focus on a detailed report impacts understanding21. Create a detailed outline with recommended sections and subsections for the final report, with flexibility for 3-40 total sections based on what the material requires22. Suggest effective ways to distribute citations throughout the report to ensure all 25-50 sources are utilized23. Evaluate implications for different stakeholders24. Suggest specific data points, statistics, or quotes that should be highlighted, always with attribution25. Identify opportunities to present contrasting viewpoints with proper citation

tasks.description: Create a comprehensive, professionally formatted research report on {research_topic} that is at least 2000-4000 words in length, incorporating findings related to {keywords} and addressing {additional_information}.IMPORTANT: Determine the structure INDEPENDENTLY based on your analysis of the research material. Create between 3-40 sections/subsections total, organized in whatever way best presents the findings. DO NOT follow any predetermined template - let the content guide the structure.Detailed steps:1. Review all research findings and the analysis report in detail, noting all source materials2. INDEPENDENTLY determine the optimal report structure based solely on the research material - do not follow a predetermined template3. Create a structured outline with main sections and subsections before writing, with the number and organization determined entirely by the research findings4. Use between 3-40 total sections and subsections, choosing a structure that best presents the research findings5. Start with a detailed title using a markdown heading level 1 (#)6. Consider whether the topic would benefit from a traditional structure or requires a more specialized approach7. Create a table of contents reflecting your chosen structure8. Write a comprehensive Executive Summary (3-4 paragraphs) that captures the essence of the report9. Create main sections (using ## headings) with the number of sections determined by the topic's complexity and research findings10. Develop subsections (using ### headings) where appropriate, allowing the material to guide the structure11. For each paragraph, write at least 4-5 complete sentences that provide in-depth information and analysis12. IMPORTANT: Include proper citations for EVERY claim, statistic, or piece of information using format (Author, Year) [X]13. For direct quotes, use quotation marks and include page numbers if available: (Author, Year, p. X) [Y]14. Aim to cite at least 25-30 different sources throughout the report to demonstrate thorough research15. Distribute citations throughout the report rather than concentrating them in a few sections16. Include specific data, statistics, and quotes from the research, with proper citation17. Create detailed visualizations or tables where appropriate using markdown formatting, citing data sources18. Ensure every claim is supported by evidence from the research with proper citation19. Where appropriate, present multiple perspectives or contradictory findings on a topic, citing each source20. Write a detailed Conclusion section that synthesizes all findings and offers future perspectives21. Compile a properly formatted References section listing ALL sources cited in the text in alphabetical order22. Format each reference entry according to a consistent citation style (APA, MLA, or Chicago)23. Verify that every in-text citation has a corresponding entry in the References section24. In the Methodology Notes section, explicitly discuss how the research depth (e.g., number of sources, diversity of perspectives) influenced the report's conclusions and limitations.25. Proofread the entire report for clarity, coherence, accuracy, grammar, and consistent formatting26. Double-check all citations for accuracy and completeness27. Ensure the total word count exceeds 2000 words at minimum
